question: Closing fast. MUSTANG, THIS IS
I don't see anything. MAVERICK, YOU HAVE A TRAILER? NEGATIVE, COUGAR. LOOKS LIKE HE'S I've got a six strobe. I think he's locked on us.
answer: It's a MiG 21. They don't have radar missiles!

question: Let's hope you're right!
He's pissing me off!
COUGAR, BREAK LEFT. TRY A HIGH G HE'S STILL ON YOU, COUGAR.
Ah, the thrill of victory and the agony of defeat.
answer: Speaking of feet, fuel's down to 4.0. We're gonna get them wet unless we find a Sonoco station.

question: Help me with this one, I'm really screwed up.
answer: Bring it left. Bring it left, You're high.

question: This is crazy!
Wait! Hell!..Something's wrong!
Were upside down!
Can't you feel it? I'm hanging in my straps!
answer: You're not. We're level. Look at the instruments, we're okay!

question: They must be broken. I'm hanging in my straps! We're inverted!
answer: We're not! Trust me! We're okay.

question: What the hell you doing?
What makes you think we can get back in? We don't have the fuel for this.
TELL HIM, WILL YOU TELL HIM? OUR
answer: YOU'RE STRAIGHT AND LEVEL, COUGAR. YEAH, COUGAR? NO JOKE, COUGAR. ON THE LEVEL.

question: Look at the weather! They'll never find us! We're near out of fuel. Put it down.
Was.
Was going. Now you are.
Well, he's going and he needs someone to fly the plane.
I didn't do it, he did it himself. Something about a wife and kid. The fact is, he's lost it. He knows it. I know it. You were up there, you know it, too.
answer: Give him a break, Skipper. It was raining snakes up there. He'll be alright, soon as all the gorillas go home...

question: I know some RIOS are a little wiggy...but you abuse the priviledge! I don't believe I'm going to have to put the two of you in the same cockpit...but there it is! It may be good for the Navy. It might be good for you, but most of all, it's good for me. It'll get you out of my sight.
answer: But, Skipper, Cougar's been picked for Top Gun...He's the best of the best!

question: Well, you'll just have to make do with him .

He's a hell of a flyer. In fact, he's so damn good he might have been picked for Top Gun himself. Except for one thing. He just can't seem to follow orders! You just did an incredibly brave thing! What you should have done was land your plane. You don't own that plane, the taxpayers do. I should ream you out for it. But it just doesn't work with you. You're a hell of a flyer. You are maybe ...too good. You never really stepped in it yet. So this is your chance. I'm gonna send you up against the best. They are better than you. Maybe they'll knock that shine off your eagle and you'll see, finally, where discipline and teamwork fit it. Maverick hasn't really heard anything but TOPGUN. He snaps out of it.
That is all. Tell me about the MiG some other time...
Maverick..
Son. Do you know why I stopped you?
Well... What is it?
answer: Sir. You are going to give me a warning, Sir!

question: License and registration. Lieutenant, do you know how fast you were going?
Well?
answer: Sir. I was going Mach point one five.

question: One SIXTH the speed of sound!
Lieutenant... What do you... usually fly?
Tomcats?
Lieutenant... Is there... a Russian attack?
answer: No sir! But you have to be ready.

question: Lieutenant.
Remember one thing.
Outside of this gate... I...am Top Gun.
...Just wondering... ...who is the best.
answer: Really... Ya know. We'd like to know who's best too. That's why we've got that plaque on the wall... with the Top Top Gun crew from each class. You think maybe your name's gonna be on it?

question: Yes sir.
answer: Considering the company you're in, that's a pretty arrogant attitude.

question: Yes sir.
answer: I like that in a fighter pilot. It's okay to be confident. You have to think you're King Kong to want to try to land on carriers. Just keep in mind the other component of success...teamwork.

question: Yes sir.
answer: Gentlemen, this is about combat. Remember, there are no points for second place. Dismissed. Viper walks out. Maverick finds Goose looking at him, quizzically. Others mill around the plaque. A big, friendly bear of a RIO speaks.

question: Gotta keep track of the competition. Slider -- they let you into Top Gun? If you're among the best in the Navy, I tremble for the security of this country.
answer: Why Goose, whose butt did you kiss to get here?

question: The list is long, but distinguished.
This is Maverick.
Who's your pilot?
No shit. The Iceman....
You think you can stay up with us.
answer: I think, yeah, we'll show you a thing or two.

question: This is Evan Mitchell, he steers the thing.
answer: So I heard. Steers it pretty close. Sorry to hear about Cougar. He was a good man.

question: Could I get a call sign?
answer: Well, I don't know. That depends.

question: On what?
answer: Well, it doesn't just happen, you gotta do something famous.

question: Like what?
Figured it out yet?
Who is the best.
Need a hint?
answer: I think I can work it out on my own.

question: You like to work alone. I've heard that about you.
answer: I've heard of you, too. You were in 124 with Bargamian.

question: And you were with Cougar. He was my roommate in flight school.
It's not Cougar's place. It's ours.
answer: What do you think it was? Was it that MiG contact that did it?

question: Did what?
Long cruise, was it? Anything I can do to help, Lieutenant?
I'll bet!
answer: Uhhh...Anything I can do for you? She laughs again, doesn't know what it is...could be chemical, but she's instinctively attracted.

question: Yeah. Hold this. It might be safer. Now I know why all the girls come here. They know how horny you guys get. But this...is ridiculous.
It isn't?
answer: Well, it is. It is that, too.

question: That's a big comfort to me.
How so?
answer: Save you from a big mistake with that other guy.

question: And on to a bigger one with you?
Was there ever a girl who didn't like fighter pilots?
I'm really flattered, Lieutenant, but I don't go out with pilots.
answer: Then what are you doing here?

question: I think the question is...what are you?
answer: Hi. I'm here to talk about a new concept in cosmetics...

question: Sorry.
answer: My fault. Should have watched where I was going.

question: Where's your wing man? Who's watching your six?
Too bad. See you around.
answer: Can I walk you out?She turns back to him, a smile.

question: I'm with someone.
Yeow! You! What are you doing here?
What if Captain Dawson had come with me?
answer: It would have been really embarrassing!

question: How did you know this was my car?
answer: Simple deduction. It's fast. It's pretty. Sleek and stylish...It's your color...matches your lipstick.

question: That's all!
You think you're pretty smart.

Hello, I think I have some new data for you...Now a MiG 21 has a problem with the inverted flight tanks. It won't do a Negative G push over. Even below one G, they risk a flame out. Operationally, they will do a zero to one G only. The latest intelligence shows that the most they will do in operation is one....is there something wrong, Lieutenant.
answer: I don't think you're altogether right...about the MiG, that is.

question: I beg your pardon.
answer: No, I beg yours. But I don't think you're right on that.

question: Why not?
You saw a MiG 21?
answer: I saw a MiG do a 4 G negative dive.

question: Where did you see that?
It's what?
answer: It's classified. Like Hollywood says, I could tell you, but then I'd have to kill you.

question: It's all right. Lieutenant, I have a top secret clearance. The Pentagon sees to it that I know more than you.
You saw a MiG push negative 4G?
Where were you?
He was in a 4G Negative dive and you were on his six?
answer: Yes, ma'am, At first. Then I was directly above him.

question: If you were directly above him, how did you see him?
You were in a 4G inverted dive with a MiG 21?
Two miles.
Lieutenant...
What were you doing there?
The what?
Why didn't you tell me you were a TAGREF?
You let me make a fool of myself.
answer: You seemed determined to do that anyway.. Why didn't you tell me you were a famous MiG insulter?

question: Would it have made a difference?
What would?
answer: You know, I'm assigned to this school. I see sixteen new hotshots every eight weeks. Your attention is flattering, but not really productive. Why don't you keep your mind on flying. Why can't you keep this straight?

question: Maverick... Where'd you get that call sign?
answer: Ahhh... Runs in the family, sir.

question: You're father was Marvin Mitchell..
A good man. Good flyer.
answer: Yes sir. Thank you sir. I've lost him -- where is he?

question: Yes sir. Thank you sir. I've lost him -- where is he?
answer: On your six -- coming hard. Four hundred. Losing airspeed! He's on your six and closing fast! Hard left! HARD LEFT! Great move. Great

question: He should've had me.
answer: Take it down. Let's bug out of here. Call for a draw.

question: No way. I'll nail him this time. Going vertical.
He's out of energy! You got control? Unload! He's right. We're at ten thousand.
answer: No way. I got you, sucker. You're going down. In the envelope. FOX TWO MISSILE SHOT. YOU'RE GONE, JESTER, DEAD!

question: Goddamn! We beat him!
Look, Ma, top of the world! Ahhh...A little high on the left, don't you think?
Right. Much better. ...Ahhh...what do you call this?
I wouldn't call it victory. It's more like...self immolation. Hi...Hi there. How ya doing in there? Mav... Ahhh...you know, at one point I did want a Navy career.
You see all those guys with gold on their shoulders!!?... Oh, no, I think that was Johnson, Air Boss of the Kitty Hawk!
answer: Come on, we beat an instructor. How many times in your life do you get to do a victory roll?

question: But you continued to fight. Why?
answer: We weren't below for more than ten seconds. There was no danger. I had the shot. I took it.

question: The rules of engagement are not flexible. They exist for your safety. You will obey them. Is that clear?
answer: Yes sir, perfectly clear. I guess we were ...I was... just a little over enthusiastic.

question: I guess you were. Dismissed.
answer: I don't know what to tell you, Skip.

question: Tell me one thing. ...If you had to go into combat, would you want him with you?
answer: Yep. He's seat of the pants... Completely unpredictable -- nothing by the book. All over the sky. But I don't know, Skip, he's really got something.

question: Yeah, we get one of these guys every damn class. "Maverick!"
What is it about you?
answer: What would you say, too fast...too quick...

question: And far too aggressive.
answer: It is combat. Every second counts.

question: The hottest moves in the world aren't gonna help you if you wind up alone. Your wingman's got to be able to follow you. Trust you. Know that he can depend on you. It's more than just fancy flying.
answer: Well, what you need...what you have to keep looking for...what you want to get is a wingman who can stay up with you. Who can match you move for move. Then you've got something. I'm sorry.

question: For what?
answer: That stuff about the MiG. I was out of line.

question: Apology acknowledged.
What else do you want?
There you go with those moves again.
I don't mix with the boys. I work here. Let's keep it professional.
Yes. I'll give you that!
answer: Give me a break, I'm asking you out.

question: I can't.
answer: I thought there was something... That night in the club...

question: Lieutenant...
Maverick...you know the rules of engagement.
Some one comes up hot on your six, what do you do?
You turn into him, check him out, identify friend or foe.
And if he's harmless, you disengage.
Uh hum.
You have to shoot him down....If he's smart, he'll turn away before that happens.
answer: Harmless. Nobody ever called me harmless before...

question: And probably never again. It's nothing personal. It's just...I know a lot of pilots. Maybe I'm immune...
answer: Don't worry, I'm a new strain. And I don't give up. Everything I've ever wanted I've had to work like hell for. Well, how about it?

question: How about what?
answer: How about anything, anything you want to do.

question: Hard to argue with that, isn't it...
answer: A date... Coffee... A drink...A walk in the park.

question: What about the plane?
Most of them invite me to sit in the cockpit...play with the levers and things.
Used to what?
I'm starting to sense that now.
answer: You're slow to engage. But you'll come around. Let's make it at eight.

question: Make what?
Okay, anything. Just...go. I've gotta work. Why'd you do that?
You're an animal.
I don't enjoy watching things suffer. No!
You're horrible
answer: You're not, cause you eat frozen meatballs? Things die. Every time you breathe, you kill millions of tiny organisms. Every time you eat, something had to die.

question: You don't have to kill it.
answer: Somebody does. It's more honest this way. You do your own dirty work.

question: You ever think about killing another human being?
answer: About as much as they think about killing me.

question: Does it bother you?
answer: They know the rules... That's the deal. That's why you're up there. It's him or me. That's the price of admission. It bothers you, why? You're part of it. Everybody dies. Most people don't get to die for something.

question: Flying?
answer: You use your mind to keep things at a distance. You ever just let go? You know what really scares me? Living too long. Losing my hair and my teeth...and my guts and my wind. And my brains...Sitting in a room with my hands in my lap, watching daytime TV.

question: You don't believe any of this. You don't think you'll ever die.
answer: That's it, of course. When I'm up there and doing it, I'm cheating it every second. I'm subverting all laws...gravity...whatever. I'm skating the edge of it.

question: Winston Churchill.
What he said..."There's nothing so exhilarating as being shot at without result."
answer: All you've got is one life. I guess it's worth about the same to every body. You ever see an old woman after her husband has died? And the meaningless years of decline stretch ahead... When you're in the air and doing something really dangerous, you can look ahead... maybe ten seconds. That's your whole future. That's as far as it goes. But imagine what those seconds are worth.

question: What if you kill yourself? Think of everything you'll miss.
answer: There is lots of stuff I don't know about... Fine wine... great art... the opera. I guess if I live long enough, I'll get to it. If I don't, I'll never miss it.

question: Are you really that brave?
answer: I watched my mother die. Cancer. She had a long time to think about it. They say you reach an agreement with death. Come to accept the fact that pretty soon you won't be here. I didn't see that. She... was very brave...braver than I am. You go up there, there isn't time to think. If you make a mistake, you're just a smudge on the ground. Simplifies funeral arrangements.

question: It's just as I thought.
You're totally insane.
answer: Thanks very much. Care for some suchi?.

question: Thanks very much. Care for some suchi?.
What?
answer: Come on, I got over six bucks on the line. Come on, come on! It's double or nothing.. We're talking twelve bucks American, here.

question: I've had enough...for now. Come on.
You want to go ballistic?
answer: I don't know. I don't like being out of control.

question: Stick with me, you'll get used to it. I always wanted to fly... ever since I first saw a jet. I wanted to fly jets, then I wanted F-14's, then I wanted to fly off carriers, then I wanted Top Gun.
And now I want you.
answer: You always get what you want?

question: I don't know yet.
Anything.
answer: No fooling on base, no signs, no comments, no talk. By anyone.

question: Why?
answer: I'm a professional. You guys are in my line of work.

question: Acknowleged.
answer: The bandit has good position right here. All right, freeze here. The moment of choice -- Maverick is defensive. He has a chance to bug out right here....Better to retire and save your plane than force a bad position. Stay in the diamond another three seconds, the bandit will blow you out of the sky...make a hard right, select zone 5... you can extend and escape. You make a bad choice. Roll forward.

question: I wasn't thinking. I just did it.
answer: Big gamble with a thirty million dollar plane!

question: A fighter pilot's lunch... a hot dog and a puke.
answer: I was a victim of circumstance.

question: They should have warned you about that one.
answer: She's kinky for flight suits--said that she'd never seen so many zippers--played with them all night. The noise alone kept me up.

question: What'd you do?
Pulled left, rolled out, underneath.
answer: It's kind of ironic. All you guys have women troubles and I don't.

question: That's because you don't have any women.
answer: Until last night. Did you see the moves I was making on that girl at the party?

question: The girl with the purple fingernails?
answer: That's her--tall hungry woman with fire in her eyes. It was great.

question: Keep your shirt on, he's saying holy shit it's us. STAY WITH HIM, WOOD... YOUR SIX CLEAR! STAY WITH HIM! TIGHTEN YOUR TURN!
answer: Bogey at three o'clock high! Nose on! Just cover Wood, Maverick. Mutual support, man!

question: I'm gonna take him, Goose.
answer: Don't be greedy. Stay with Wood.

question: I want him!
answer: Hey, come on--hey! What what are you doing? We're cover!

question: Wood's okay. I want Viper.
What's the range, Goose. I've got a good tone.
answer: Two bogies ! Three o'clock high, nine o'clock high! Break!

question: KNOCK OFF THE CHATTER, TOP GUNS. Ya know, that was the best flying I've seen since Nam... ...Right up to that part where you got killed. Twenty years' experience, I couldn't shake you. You may be a great flyer. I mean that.

Of course you did. I said a great flyer, not a smart one. You fly reckless. Great instincts. No discipline. That ambush today, you followed your emotions instead of your wingman. Of course you got killed...and well deserved to. It was a really stupid mistake. In battle, it gets people killed.
answer: I can take care of myself.

question: Talent is no holy shield. Von Richtofen was killed by a farm boy. Instincts are not enough. Do it our way. We've worked these things out. The good pilots can become better and the great ones can learn how to stay alive. Why do you have to do everything the hard way?
answer: It's my own way. It works for me. I don't care about the rest of that stuff.

question: Then why are you here?
answer: For the same reason you are.

question: Oh, you mean the thrill!
answer: The flying. The fighting. I'd go up there ten times a day to fight. I'd win at least nine of them. That's all I want to do. It's what I do best. I am real good. Just give me the jet.

question: Food...and you...my F-14!
Well no...inverse order.
You ever fly an F-14?
answer: I don't fly in anything that doesn't show movies.

question: Ahhh, you'd love it. Night carrier landings! The most dangerous thing you can think of! ...next to you...And the most exciting. You're living at one hundred and ten per cent. Greatest high in the world...
. Yeah!
Why, what's gonna happen? Lucky charm.
answer: What do you take me for? It's a Navy Cross.

question: Just good luck.
SHIT!!
answer: GET OUT OF THERE, YOU'RE UNSAFE.

question: FIRE, OR CLEAR OUT, ICE.
answer: GET LOST! STAY OUT OF IT. STAY OUT OF IT,

question: YOU CAN'T SHOOT HIM, I CAN. I'M IN. ICE, ROLL OFF, I CAN SHOOT HIM.
IF YOU CAN'T SHOOT HIM, I CAN.
answer: NO, I GOT HIM. I CAN TAKE HIM. Sonofabitch. LOOK OUT!

question: Oh, no! Plane's coupling up! Plane's coupling up! This is not good!... We're low!
Time to go.
3000 feet. I'll do it.
answer: Go ahead. I can't reach. 2000 feet! Let's go. Eject.

question: Go ahead. I can't reach. 2000 feet! Let's go. Eject.
All right.
I know. I was there.
answer: If you fly jets long enough, something like this happens to you. No one escapes it. It touches us all.

question: He was...my responsibility--my RIO.
answer: My first squadron in Vietnam, we lost eight out of eighteen planes. Ten guys. The first one kills you, but there'll be others--you can count on it. You've got to put him in the box.

question: ...they say you're alright.
This is it, then.
The dark side. The price you pay for all the fun you're having. You knew about it, of course. Didn't you?
answer: He was a friend of mine. A good guy...great guy. It was my fault.

question: That's not what I hear.
That's what you get flight pay for.
Why? You act like you didn't know one day this would happen.
You knew it. You all do. It's part of it. Maybe the most important part.
Where are we? You know where we are. It's called the beach. It's where life first crawled up out of the sea. I come here sometimes... when I feel like crawling back in.
answer: You don't have to do this.

question: Do what, show you a good time?
answer: I'm not good company. I should be alone.

question: I don't think so, but if that's what you want...
What do you want?
What?
You look way out there. Out past the date line. West becomes East, all things change. You cross the line...today becomes yesterday...or tomorrow, I forget which.

Of course the line's just imaginary. You can cross it twenty times...nothing really changes. On the beach... It's what they say when Navy men retire...He's "On The Beach". I always liked that. I had a picture...in my head... all these old guys wandering around here, looking out into the past.
answer: If we knew then, what we know now, we might never have come up out of there.

question: You don't believe that.
Only when you're depressed. Then it passes.
Everything passes. Immutable law of the Universe. This too...shall pass. You put as much life as you can between it and you. You start piling up experience between then and now.
answer: What do you do when you come here?

question: I sit. I think. I play games.
I like to play "reality".
It's strip reality, actually, like what the pilots always want to play.
answer: Strip reality! How do you play that?

question: It's like strip poker, only, without the bluffing. One person says something and if the other one accepts that it's true, the one who says it, gets to take one item of clothing off.
answer: You're crazy. That's a pretty silly game.

question: Not as silly as some. You know the silliest one? ...that we are gods. That we control events on the beach... that we can turn back time... Want to play the game?
You say the truth. Go ahead. Don't be afraid. You want to win the game, don'tcha?
The big one. The one that's most on your mind.
True.
Take something off.
That's up to you. It's dangerous...what you do.
You can't bring him back.
Nope. Already used that. Your life goes on.
That wasn't fair. It was a question. Penalty round! You didn't mean it. You didn't think. You'd do anything to take it back.
And that's one!
Your watch.
Looks like a tie.
He just won't engage. He can't do it, Skipper. He can't get back on the horse.
answer: It's only been a week. Keep sending him up.

question: I've seen this before.
What are you doing?
Since when did you care about paperwork? If I could fly like you I'd have everything I want. If I could fly at all. I can't fly. I can't fly like that. Nobody can. Whatever it is, you've got it!
Never liked fighter pilots anyway.
answer: You came to the right place.

question: I'll have what he's having... Hemlock, is it? You weren't gonna say goodbye?
Long distance? I wouldn't do that to you. I'd at least talk to you.
answer: I didn't want to see you. I mean, I did...but I didn't..

question: I know exactly what you mean.

I've got a gift just like you do. My gift is I just know what people mean, even if they can't say it. It helps when you're trying to communicate with fighter pilots. Like what you just said was "I'm embarrassed, I feel I've done something wrong, that I've failed, and I don't think I can live up to the expectations of a wonderful interesting, intelligent woman like yourself." That about it?
And I'm gonna sneak off, and be by myself for awhile, like until I can think of a new career...hotel management or something...
answer: Big talk for someone who's never been shot off her computer.

question: Hey, I never said I was a fighter pilot...I never claimed to think it was fun to be shot off the end of a ship in a storm. I can find contentment in a good book. I don't have to roar by someone at Mach two with my hair on fire. Sometimes...I just get happy being with the right man.
I don't know, Tim. You'll have to ask them. Runs in the family...
No bother.
My wife's house.
answer: She said you took your kid to the each. Every second Sunday. Zoo or beach or the ballgame. Y'have the option... What about me?

question: We can send you back to your squadron with nothing noted on your record except "CNC" --course not completed, no explanation required. Theoretically, it doesn't hurt your career, but people always wonder about things like that.
Or you can quit.
I didn't know either. That's why I told Jester to prepare your papers.
answer: You've already made up your mind.

question: It's no disgrace, kid. That spin was hell. It would wreck anyone's confidence. You could be a good pilot again someday...
I didn't say that. That's up to you. But I have responsibility for the other guys up there, not just you. They need to know you're all right...that they can depend on you.
answer: Here, let me get this. We'll be even. Lucky charm.

question: Sometimes it's luck, but in this case, he earned it... I served with your old man.
VF 51, the Oriskany. You remind me of him. You're just like he was, only better...and worse.
You may not think so, but you are.
answer: He was by the book, all the way.

question: They waved him off. He thought he knew better. He hit the ramp.
Not something they tell dependents.

Why would I lie? You start on a wrong heading... the more you stick to it, the further you get from your target. A good pilot always questions himself, always questions his judgments, stays alert for drift and makes the corrections...You may find a little discipline helps with the fear. You don't have to be alone up there.
answer: How can I go on? I feel so... responsible.

question: Kid, the plain fact is...you are. I'm not gonna stand here and blow sunshine up your ass. Technically, they absolved you. You and I know what really happened. You pushed it. You are responsible and you'll always carry that. You know what, I'll carry it too. I should have taken you out of that cockpit. I guess I'm a hopeless romantic... I always try to find something worthwhile in someone's death. It's no trade-off. It's not one for one. What you learned isn't worth his death. It couldn't be. But maybe there is some value in it. I know it's the first thing I've ever seen that's really gotten to you. Now the question is, what will you do with it. If it gets you out of flight status...so you don't kill yourself or anybody else...that's good. That's one good thing. You were an accident waiting to happen.
I didn't say that. That's up to you. I think that if you do, if you choose to come back, you'll be a better pilot... a better man.
answer: Would you take me back? Would they?

question: MUSTANG, THIS IS VOODOO ONE,
MUSTANG, WE HAVE FOUR MIGS IN THE
Let's go! Dive on those bastards! Come on, man, engage. This is it. Get your nose in there. Bandit at seven o'clock low--solo. Take him. Pull on the goddamn stick, man!
Don't tell me okay. Do it!
BREAK LEFT! BREAK LEFT! CHAFF! FLARES!
AH, SHIT! GODDAMN IT!
Zone 5 burners.
answer: We're ballistic! Ohhhhhh Shit! Ohhh Mother!

question: Goddamnit, Mav, you really are a slow learner. Don't worry, Fung, I've got it.
answer: Don't WORRY!!!? You've GOT it!!? Are you CRAZY?

question: Roger, I've got it.
answer: You've got it? Good! Cause for a minute there, you had me worried. Now have you got it? Have you still got it?

question: Yawing right.
Rudder's left, stick's forward.
I've got it -- hold on!
I can recover. Hold on! You with me?
answer: Right behind you. Speed's up to 150. 5000 feet. Speed two hundred.

question: Okay.
No! Not again!
answer: What are you talking about, we gotta go!

question: I'm not losing it again!
280, 290, 300 knots.
answer: 3,000 feet. We gotta go, man. 3,000 feet, we gotta go!

question: You go. I'm staying with it.
answer: I'm gonna go! THREE...TWO...ONE... What in the Christ...was that? Did you plan that? Was all that something you planned?

question: ALL RIGHT, ICE. COME HARD STARBOARD, THEN EXTEND TO THE EAST.
answer: Because...if that was... Next time you tell me first.

question: WHEN I SHOOT, YOU BREAK LEFT..3..2 HE FIRED, BREAK NOW! He's out! We got him!
answer: What a dope! Maybe they'll give him another plane...and we can shoot him down again. What is it? What's wrong? Is there something I should know?

question: Just relax.
The plane is fine.
I guess I owe you one.
answer: You don't owe me anything. We're on the same team.

question: You saved our lives. You did it!
You're a hell of a flyer. You can be my wingman any time.
You hear that? Anything we want. Anything...Well???
What do you want?
What do you want?
